Fiction

THE BROKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The C.I.A. arranges a presidential pardon for a power broker who may know crucial secrets, laying a trap for the foreign intelligence service that wants him dead.

THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.

THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
BY ORDER OF THE PRESIDENT, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer tries to thwart a terrorist plot to crash a stolen 727 into the Liberty Bell.
CHAINFIRE, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) The 10th volume of the ''Sword of Truth'' fantasy series.

NIGHT FALL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A husband and wife who work for an antiterrorism task force reopen the investigation into the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 over the Atlantic, off Long Island, in 1996.
UNEXPECTED BLESSINGS, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Continuing the story of the Harte family and its financial empire, told through four generations of women.
A SALTY PIECE OF LAND, by Jimmy Buffett. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A cowboy's life is changed when a 101-year-old woman hires him to be a lighthouse keeper.
LONDON BRIDGES, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The F.B.I. agent Alex Cross contends with two deadly enemies: the Wolf and the Weasel.
I AM CHARLOTTE SIMMONS, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.95.) A very smart, very innocent freshman from the Blue Ridge Mountains is amazed by what she finds at a prestigious university.
BLACK WIND, by Clive Cussler and Dirk Cussler. (Putnam, $27.95.) Dirk Pitt and his children confront a villain who has acquired biotoxins from World War II.

GILEAD, by Marilynne Robinson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) A story of fathers and sons that reaches back to the abolitionist movement and into the 1950's, narrated by a 76-year-old Iowa pastor who is dying.

THE PLOT AGAINST AMERICA, by Philip Roth. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The experiences of a Jewish family in Newark after Charles A. Lindbergh defeats Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1940 presidential election.
THE CAT WHO WENT BANANAS, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam, $23.95.) Jim Qwilleran and his cats investigate the suspicious death of an actor.

List
Nonfiction
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of ''The Tipping Point'' explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
WITNESS, by Amber Frey. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A memoir by the California massage therapist who testified for the prosecution in the murder trial of Scott Peterson.
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $29.95.) A historical investigation, by the author of ''Guns, Germs, and Steel,'' into why some societies succeed while others fail.
AMERICA (The BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin, David Javerbaum et al. (Warner, $24.95.) ''The Daily Show'' offers an illustrated parody of a civics textbook.

GOD'S POLITICS, by Jim Wallis. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.) An evangelical Christian argues that Democrats must ''take back the faith'' and not allow conservative Republicans to hijack the Bible. (+)
EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks.
ANIMALS IN TRANSLATION, by Temple Grandin and Catherine Johnson. (Scribner, $25.) How autism can help lead to an understanding of the brains, emotions and talents of animals.
HIS EXCELLENCY, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.95.) A biography of George Washington, by the author of ''Founding Brothers.''
FAVRE, by Brett Favre and Bonita Favre with Chris Havel. (N.F.L. Publishing/RuggedLand, $29.95.) A profusely illustrated book about the Green Bay Packers' quarterback.
WINNING THE FUTURE, by Newt Gingrich. (Regnery, $27.95.) The former speaker of the House proposes a 21st-century ''Contract With America.'' (+)
WHEN WILL JESUS BRING THE PORK CHOPS? by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $23.95.) Another volume of observations and opinions from the stand-up comedian.
CHRONICLES: Volume One, by Bob Dylan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) Recollections and observations from the singer-songwriter.
102 MINUTES, by Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn. (Times Books/Holt, $26.) Two journalists at The New York Times describe people's struggle to survive inside the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
HOW TO TALK TO A LIBERAL (IF YOU MUST), by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $26.95.) A collection of the columnist's writings about what's wrong with liberals.
WILL IN THE WORLD, by Stephen Greenblatt. (Norton, $26.95.) A Harvard humanities professor sets out to explain how Shakespeare became the greatest of all playwrights.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Jan. 22, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest
THE HA-HA, by Dave King. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) A first novel whose narrator's powers of speech were wrecked in Vietnam; his exchanges with a 9-year-old boy are good for both of them.
EPILEPTIC, by David B. (Pantheon, $25.) This memoir in graphic form about an elder brother's affliction is also a cultural and intellectual history, with iconographies by the artist.
A COMPLICATED KINDNESS, by Miriam Toews. (Counterpoint, $23.) A novel told by a girl mismatched with her Mennonite hometown.
TRAWLER, by Redmond O'Hanlon. (Knopf, $25.) To sea with a fishing crew in the dreadful North Atlantic, by a bookish Briton who likes to risk his neck now and then.
BRASS, by Helen Walsh. (Canongate, paper, $14.) No sweet talk in this raw-spoken coming-of-age novel about a hard-nosed Liverpool girl.
ASTONISHING SPLASHES OF COLOUR, by Clare Morrall. (HarperCollins, $23.95.) A woman, 32, who has lost both baby and womb, can't take care of herself in this grim novel.
AMERICAN PURGATORIO, by John Haskell. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) Dante, the deadly sins and Brooklyn in a weird first novel.

EXTREME WEATHER: A Guide & Record Book, by Christopher C. Burt. (Norton, paper, $24.95.) An exploration of Nature's angry moods, showing that they seem to be getting even more extreme; warnings for everybody.
HOME LAND, by Sam Lipsyte. (Picador, paper, $13.) Lipsyte's antihero, a loser but unbowed, asserts in endless letters to his alumni magazine that all the others are losers too.
BICYCLE: The History, by David V. Herlihy. (Yale University, $35.) A prodigious researcher recounts the development of a great machine that wasn't fully practical till the 1870's.

IMPERIAL RECKONING: The Untold Story of Britain's Gulag in Kenya, by Caroline Elkins. (Holt, $27.50.) A professor of history at Harvard, Elkins examines the physical and moral atrocities perpetrated by colonialism in the 1950's.
The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books
